metadata.case_name: Muthappa Chettiar v. Income-Tax Officer and Others
metadata.case_number: Civil Appeal No. 107 of 1956 (with Petition No. 130 of 1958)

facts.text: Muthappa Chettiar and Thyagrajan Chettiar were partners in Muthappa Co., started in November 1940, managing agent of Saroja Mills Ltd. in Coimbatore district.
Relevant chargeable accounting periods for Excess Profits Tax: calendar year 1942 and broken period January 1, 1943 to March 4, 1943.
Income-tax assessment for same periods completed by Income-Tax Officer on March 15, 1948, under s.23(2)(b) Income-tax Act, 1922; appellant paid his share.
Thyagrajan Chettiar published notice in The Hindu announcing dissolution of firm as from March 4, 1943, and informed Income Tax Officer.
Income Tax Officer inquired of appellant about dissolution; appellant replied by letter dated February 1, 1945, disputing dissolution, stating suit filed against Thyagrajan in Coimbatore Sub-Court.
Appellant filed suit O.S. 50 of 1946 in Coimbatore Sub-Court contesting validity of dissolution notice, seeking declaration of invalidity, court decree for dissolution from future date, and accounts.
Subordinate Judge upheld validity of dissolution by Thyagrajan in 1943 (judgment 1948).
Appellant appealed to Madras High Court; appeal allowed in 1953, fixing dissolution date as March 10, 1949; further appeal pending in Supreme Court.
Excess Profits Tax assessment completed by Excess Profits Tax Officer on March 31, 1951, notices served only on Thyagrajan Chettiar as managing partner; income computed same as Income-tax.
Managing agency remuneration: Rs.1,02,219 for 1942, Rs.6,387 for broken period; Saroja Mills debited full amount but withheld Rs.89,137 in suspense due to dispute over mill extension obligations.

Appellant filed Writ Petition No.498 of 1952 in Madras High Court for writ of prohibition against coercive recovery by Income-Tax Officer, E.P.T. Circle, Madras; also challenged assessment but dismissed as not germane.
Madras High Court dismissed writ petition on January 21, 1954.
Supreme Court granted special leave: Civil Appeal No.107 of 1956.
Appellant filed Petition No.130 of 1958 under Art.32 Constitution in Supreme Court to quash EPT assessment order.

legal_issues.text: Whether Excess Profits Tax assessment valid without notice to appellant, given alleged dissolution of firm and notices only to Thyagrajan Chettiar.
Whether inclusion of Rs.89,137 withheld remuneration as income valid for EPT, despite dispute with Saroja Mills.
Whether coercive recovery under s.46 Income-tax Act valid against appellant without personal notice of demand under s.29.

petitioner_arguments.text: Firm dissolved as from March 4, 1943 (or March 10, 1949 per High Court); mutual agency ceased; notice only to Thyagrajan invalid, does not bind appellant or firm.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Excess Profits Tax Act, 1940 s.13 (notice requirement)

petitioner_arguments.text: Rs.89,137 not accrued income as withheld by Mills due to default on obligations; not includible.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Commissioner of Income-tax v. K.R.M.T.T. Thiagaraja Chetty & Co.

petitioner_arguments.text: Appellant not 'assessee' but 'other person liable'; no personal s.29 demand notice; coercive process under s.46(2) inapplicable; only suit possible.

respondent_arguments.text: Appellant estopped from claiming dissolution at assessment time (1951) as he denied it in 1945 letter and suit; matter res sub-judice.
Under EPT Act, business (not firm) is unit of assessment; notice to managing partner during chargeable periods sufficient even post-dissolution; s.44 IT Act as modified applies.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Excess Profits Tax Act, 1940 ss.8,13,14,21,44 IT Act, s.63 IT Act

court_reasoning.text: Appellant precluded/estopped from pleading dissolution in 1951 as he consistently denied it till High Court decision in 1953; assessment validity not retrospective.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellant's 1945 letter and pending suit treated firm as continuing; High Court appeal pending at assessment time.

court_reasoning.text: Even if dissolved, EPT assesses business; notice to person in management during chargeable periods valid; partners jointly/severally liable per modified s.44 IT Act; s.63 allows notice to partner.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No difference in assessment method for running or dissolved firm businesses.

court_reasoning.text: Rs.89,137 accrued as Mills debited full remuneration, claimed deduction; cross-claim irrelevant; same as IT assessment upheld.
Appellant is 'assessee' per s.21 proviso EPT Act; s.29 demand on managing partner binds via s.63; assessee in default, arrears recoverable under s.46.

holdings.text: EPT assessment order dated March 31, 1951 valid and binding on appellant.
Inclusion of managing agency remuneration valid.
Coercive recovery under s.46 IT Act valid against appellant.

precedents_cited.case_name: A.O. Pandu Rao v. Collector of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Notice to managing partner post-dissolution valid for EPT assessment of business; partners jointly liable.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras v. K.R.M.T.T. Thiagaraja Chetty & Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: Accrual of income despite cross-claim; against appellant.
Notice to partner treated as notice to all under s.63 IT Act.

statutes_cited.name: Excess Profits Tax Act, 1940
statutes_cited.relevance: Business as unit of assessment; notice provisions; applicability of IT Act sections; proviso deems partners assessees.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Assessment, demand notice, recovery machinery, service on partner, joint/several liability post-discontinuance.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Petition for enforcement of fundamental rights, writ of certiorari.

outcome.summary: Writ Petition 130 of 1958 dismissed as EPT assessment valid. Civil Appeal 107 of 1956 dismissed; High Court order upheld, recovery proceedings valid.

key_quotes.text: "the assessment of the managing agency business to Excess Profits Tax was properly and legally effected by notice to Thyagrajan Chettiar."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Notice, therefore, to a partner is treated as notice to all."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains s.63 IT Act application to EPT.

key_quotes.text: "the appellant was an assessee in default within s.46(1) of the Income-tax Act and the amount of tax and penalty due from him would be an arrear within s.46(2)."
key_quotes.speaker: court
